EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:  
H.B. Fuller's Worldwide Environment, Health, Safety and Security Policy states they are committed to protecting the environment and the health, safety, and security of our associates, our customers, and the public. All associates are responsible for the successful implementation of this policy as follows:
¿We implement environmental, health, safety, and security (EHSS) programs that are, at a minimum, in compliance with applicable governmental 
 requirements and internal standards.
¿These programs are consistent with standard worldwide requirements established and maintained by the H.B. Fuller Worldwide Environment, 
 Health, Safety, and Security (WEHSS) Committee.
¿We are proactive in addressing unsafe behaviors and conditions.
¿We are committed to pollution prevention by striving to prevent the release of any pollutant that may cause adverse effects to the 
 environment, minimize the creation of waste, especially hazardous waste, reduce and, where possible, eliminate the EHSS risks to our  
 associates, customers, and the communities in which we operate.
¿We are committed to continual improvement in our performance through awareness, prevention, and employee involvement in EHSS programs.
¿We establish EHSS objectives and targets, conduct regular management systems and performance evaluations, and report our performance to our 
 stakeholders.
Policy closes by stating "The Operating Committee has the primary responsibility to implement programs that are developed to comply with this policy. And all managers and supervisors shall ensure compliance with this policy within their area of responsibility". 
Bendix Warehouse has implemented and maintains a management system to receive, manufacture, and ship products and materials in a manner that conforms to the Worldwide Environment, Health, Safety and Security Policy by managing operations with the goal of protecting pe

rsonnel and the community while doing no harm to the environment. The Bendix Warehouse accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are fully supported by the management of H.B. Fuller. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to notify the St. Joseph County 9-1-1 Dispatch Center who notifies applicable agencies and departments, such as South Bend Fire Department, to respond to the emergency. 
 
2. Bendix Warehouse and the Regulated Substances Handled:
The Bendix Warehouse is operated Royal Adhesives & Sealants, LLC which is an indirect, wholly owned subsidiary of H.B. Fuller Company. Since 2016, the Bendix Warehouse serves as a distribution center and aerosol container filling process for its industrial adhesive products.
The facility is located on a 4.49-acre site and is in an industrial neighborhood on the West side of North Bendix Drive, in the Northwestern section of the City of South Bend, Indiana. The facility has only one occupant with two applicable North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) Codes which are NAICS Code 49311 (General Warehousing and Storage) and NAICS Code 32552 (Adhesive Manufacturing).
The 4.49-acre site contains approximately 64,500-square foot building that occupies much of the property. This facility operates five (5) days a week, with occasional overtime on the weekends, and is closed for US holidays. There are seasonal inventory fluctuations, but the employees normally work a day shift from 6 AM - 4 PM. Throughout most of the facility it operates as a chemical warehouse that receives, stores and ships chemicals used to manufacturer solvent and water-based industrial adhesives and sealants, commercial roofing adhesives, mirror mastics and epoxies as well shipping finished products to customers.

In the west side of the facility is the Aerosol Canister/Can Filling Line Process used to fill pressurized containers with adhesive products and flush products. The process is designed to fill DOT 39

her H.B. Fuller facilities are normally stored in sealed containers on unitized pallets at this facility prior to shipment or use.

3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Bendix Warehouse facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the EPA's accidental release prevention requirements as set forth in 40 CFR part 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at our stationary source. 
This facility is subject to Program Level 3 requirements including a management system, hazard assessment, and emergency response requirements. A management system has been developed and maintained that identifies personnel roles or job titles responsible for maintaining each element of the facility's Risk Management Program (RMP) including documentation, change communication and change implementation for applicable RMP program elements. Hazard assessments have been completed for worst-case scenarios and alternate case scenarios for the Aerosol Storage Area #1 and the Aerosol Canister/Can Filling Process. These scenarios have been reviewed during tabletop exercises with St. Joseph County Emergency Management Agency, South Bend Fire Department, South Bend Police Department, and other local responders resulting in the facility's implementation of an Emergency Response Program that is coordinated with local responders.  
Program Level 3 requires a full prevention program similar to OSHA's PSM Standard including Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Pre-Startup Review, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Hot Work Permits and Contractors. Also, the facility is required to implement an Emergency Response Program that is coordinated with local responders.
  
Process Safety Information: 
Bendix Warehouse maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemic

al hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with the Aerosol Storage Area #1 and the Canister/Can Filling Process. Process safety information applicable for our operations has been prepared in accordance with regulatory requirements and good engineering practices, including consideration of applicable industrial standards and best practices. Process safety information along with incident history and other applicable data including emergency response exercises with local first responders are all necessary to complete a thorough process hazard analysis. 

Process Hazard Analysis:
The facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled effectively. The Zurich Hazard Analysis methodology, HAZOP methodology and along with a What If/Checklist method were used to identify hazards, determine risk for each hazard identified, and documented on a register to track findings which are addressed in a timely manner. The PHAs for both processes were led by an experienced facilitator with team members representing warehouse employees (with knowledge specific to the process being evaluated), lab employees (with knowledge specific to the process being evaluated), supervision, maintenance, process engineering, and safety. Some of the major risks identified included fire, explosion, over pressurization, earthquake, tornado, powered industrial truck hazards and personal safety hazards.  

Operating Procedures: The Bendix Warehouse maintains written operating procedures to ensure that activities within our covered processes are conducted safely. These procedures address various modes of operation; the information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. 

Training: 
The Bendix Warehouse has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with t

hese processes.

Mechanical Integrity: 
The facility has a written Mechanical Integrity Procedure that is used to maintain the integrity of Canister/Can Filling Process and Aerosol Storage Area #1 equipment. The procedure includes equipment inspection, testing and preventative maintenance (ITPM) using recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices, follows a schedule that matches the manufacturer's recommendations or more frequently if prior operating experience indicates is necessary and documents each ITPM activity in accordance with regulatory requirements. Examples of process equipment receiving ITPM include pressure vessels, storage containers, piping systems, fire protection/fire suppression system, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Equipment deficiencies are corrected before further use of process equipment or whenever necessary to ensure safety. ITPM is performed by qualified personnel with previous maintenance training. Also, training of process maintenance employees includes an overview of the process and its hazards and covers the covers the procedures applicable to safe job performance. The written procedure contains a Quality Assurance element or program for new construction & equipment, newly installed equipment, maintenance materials, and spare parts & equipment.
  
Management of Change:
Written procedures are in place at the facility to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, organization, and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel, warehouse personnel, or other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly notified of the modification and offered training to safely deal with the change. 

Pre-startup Reviews: 
The facility performs pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and modifications in established processes in accordance with written procedures. These reviews are conducted to confirm that co

nstruction, equipment, and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits:
Bendix Warehouse performs compliance audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions of the plan, as set out under 40 CFR part 68, are being implemented. Any non-compliance issue discovered during the audit is promptly corrected.

Incident Investigation:
The facility initiates incident investigations in accordance 40 CFR part 68. Additionally, the Bendix Warehouse procedure specifies that all accidental releases be investigated since minor accident or near miss investigations may help identify problems that could result in major releases if left unaddressed. Incident investigation findings are promptly addressed to prevent recurrence. Velocity EHS is used to report incidents and audit findings and track action items to completion. The Corporate incident reporting procedure defines when a root cause analysis must be performed. H.B. Fuller uses the Cause Map methodology as the default methodology for root cause analyses. Other methodologies may be utilized at the discretion of the facilitator.

Employee Participation:
H.B. Fuller genuinely believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. Any Bendix Warehouse employee is strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP particularly information resulting from process hazard analyses (PHAs). 

Hot Work Permit: 
Hot work permit procedures can be found in the relevant standard operating procedure (SOP), safe work practice manual, or operations or maintenance guide that the stationary source uses to inform personnel when and how to perform hot work. For the stationary source's first RMP, the owner or operator should enter the date of

the last review of these procedures in Section 7.13, ensuring compliance with the hot work permit requirements in §68.85. For subsequent RMPs, the owner or operator should provide the date of the most recent review or revision of the hot work permit procedures. Hot work permit procedures may be reviewed or revised as a result of, among other things, a periodic audit of the prevention program (§68.79(a)). If the procedures were not reviewed or revised since the previous RMP was submitted, the owner or operator may retain the date provided in the previous RMP.

Contractors:
Both the Bendix Warehouse personnel and its contractors have responsibilities where contractors perform maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to the Awrosol Canister/Can Filling Process or Aerosol Storage Area #1. Bendix Warehouse contractor procedure includes checking safety performance when selecting a contractor, providing safety and hazards information, maintaining a contractor employee occupational injury/illness log, ensuring safe practices and verifying that contractor acts responsibility by verifying that contractor is fulfilling its responsibilities. The contractor must ensure training for its employees, ensure its employees know the process hazards and applicable emergency actions, document training, ensure its employees are following Bendix Warehouse safety procedures, and inform Bendix Warehouse personnel of hazards presented by its work or any hazards it finds during performance of work.

4. The five-year accident history:
The Bendix Warehouse has been operated as Royal Adhesives & Sealants, LLC since 2016 and from that time to the present, has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years. The Bendix Warehouse has not had a PSM incident or OSHA recordable case in the history of the facility. 

5. The emergency response program:
The Bendix Warehouse emergency response program is written in an Int

egrated Contingency Plan (ICP) format which is intended to respond to contingencies that integrates the requirements of multiple government agencies into one combined document. A contingency can be a spill, release, fire, earthquake, traffic accident, or any other emergency condition that threatens the environment, public safety, employees in a workplace, or other specified subjects; and that would require an emergency response of some kind. The plan is designed to ensure that the facility has the necessary resources available to effectively respond to emergency incidents and is designed and maintained to promote prompt and effective action intended to minimize hazards to human health and/or the environment if an emergency occurs.

Bendix Warehouse personnel are trained and expected to follow their Emergency Action Plan (EAP), in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.38, and the guidelines contained in their Integrated Contingency Plan. If an incidental spill or release of a hazardous material is observed or discovered, Bendix Warehouse employees are trained to stop or control a small release. If a small (incipient) stage fire is discovered, Bendix Warehouse employees may extinguish the fire providing they have had training on portable fire extinguisher use and hazards involved with incipient stage firefighting. If an emergency beyond the small or incipient stage were to occur, it is our policy to notify St. Joseph County 9-1-1 Dispatch Center who notifies applicable agencies and departments, such as South Bend Fire Department, to respond to the emergency. 

The Bendix Warehouse EAP considers that major incidents or events are beyond warehouse employees' training and resources. Hence, the EAP contains Standard Operating Guidelines (SOGs) that describe the actions taken by warehouse employees along with the actions taken by external responders, as applicable, to stop, control or mitigate the event while focusing on the Overall Priorities-Life Safety, Incident Stabilization

and Property Conservation. The Bendix Warehouse Emergency Action Plan contained in the Integrated Contingency Plan addresses medical emergency, warehouse chemical release, warehouse fire, canister/can filling process chemical spill or gas release, canister/can filling process fire, transportation incidents, tornado, evacuation, shelter-in-place, utility outages, earthquake, and security threats.
 
Coordinated response actions with outside resources is extremely important and HB Fuller's Environment, Health and Safety Specialist supporting the Bendix Warehouse is a primary member of the St. Joseph County Local Emergency Planning Committee. Bendix Warehouse employees' response actions to spills or releases of regulated flammable substances will be coordinated with the South Bend Fire Department. 

A tabletop exercise was held on May 15, 2020, to review the Bendix Warehouse Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) for the warehouse and Aerosol Storage Area #1 with a focus on achieving three objectives (1) Increased awareness and understanding of hazards and the potential impacts of hazards, (2) Clarify roles and responsibilities, and (3) Obtain participant feedback and recommendations for program improvement. These objectives were achieved by focusing on Bendix Warehouse ICP Section 5. Personnel Roles and Responsibilities and Section 6: Emergency Action Plan-Initial Response-Warehouse Employees and Sustained Actions -External Resources. Also, the worst-case scenario and alternate case scenarios were reviewed illustrating impacted areas from releases of a DOT Hazard Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas) aerosol.  Exercise participants represented the South Bend Police Department, South Bend Fire Department, St. Joseph County EMA, South Bend Wastewater Treatment Facility, and the St. Joseph County Airport Authority. HB Fuller exercise participants represented the Bendix Warehouse, South Bend Plant, Region and Corporate Office. Because of the COVID-19 pandemic restrictions, the meeting

was held using Cisco WebEx Meeting conferencing platform and personnel attendance was confirmed during the meeting. Recommendations were identified and were implemented in Section 6: Emergency Action Plan-Initial Response-Warehouse Employees and Sustained Actions-External Resources. 

Project conception meetings for proposed Bendix Warehouse Aerosol Canister and Can Filling Process were held with local first responders on July 29 and August 03, 2020. Representatives from South Bend Fire Department, South Bend Police Department, and South Bend International Airport Department of Public Safety were in attendance. Topics discussed were worst-case scenarios with potential offsite impacts for an LPG vessel and dimethyl ether vessel. Equipment locations, process controls, mitigation systems and detection systems planned for this new process were reviewed as well. A significant recommendation was made by the fire department to install a fire hydrant north of the warehouse and a project change was initiated to install the fire hydrant. There were not any additional changes or issues identified that would prevent construction of the new process. 

A tabletop exercise sponsored by St. Joseph County LEPC was held on February 18, 2021, for the Bendix Warehouse Aerosol Canister and Can Filling Process. The exercise followed Indiana DHS-Homeland Security Exercise and Evaluation Program (HSEEP) guidelines. Attendance included representatives from South Bend Police Department, South Bend Fire Department, St. Joseph County EMA, South Bend Wastewater Treatment Facility, Memorial Hospital-South Bend, Beacon Health System, and U.S. DHS Region V, Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency. H.B. Fuller exercise participants represented the Bendix Warehouse Facility, South Bend Plant, Region and Corporate Office. Exercise mission was described as Response with Core Capabilities-Public Information and Warning as well as Operational Coordination. Exercise objectives included Public

Information and Warning, Operational Coordination, Fire Management and Suppression, Environmental Response/Health and Safety, and On-scene Security, Protection, and Law Enforcement. Recommendations related to notification and coordination with local first responders were identified and implemented in Bendix Warehouse ICP Section 5. Personnel Roles and Responsibilities and Section 6: Emergency Action Plan-Initial Response-Warehouse Employees and Sustained Actions-External Resources. 

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety: 
Planned changes to improve safety include making operating procedures and training better with even more employee involvement in changes related to the Aerosol Canister/Can Filling Process and continually improve on the already successful powered industrial truck (forklift) operator's recertification program. Also, continuous improvement with greater emphasis on employee participation assisting management in the review of other applicable RMP management system elements.
